title.narrative: Marine Turtle Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to provide technical and scientific support for leatherback and other sea turtle conservation projects in the West African region. The Recipient will conduct workshops, meet with individual projects to provide technical and scientific expertise in Gabon, Equatorial Guinea, Sao Tome and Principe, Ivory Coast and Republic of Congo as well as carry out conservation work on the human turtle conflict in Corsica Bay area between Gabon and Equatorial Guinea.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Great Apes Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to contribute to the conservation of the West African chimpanzee in Liberia by providing the next generation of Liberias natural resource managers with the tools to conduct both applied research and implement conservation programs to international standards. Design and implement a five-day residential training course covering field research methods; establish a small, accessible library of books, papers and reports relevant to the study and conservation of Liberian biodiversity; clear and map a trail system in the park for use by researchers, rangers and tourists; host national and international researchers to conduct applied research work; train a minimum of 5 community members in basic guiding skills; disseminate research findings through scientific publications, a dedicated website, local and national media and reports to the Forestry Development Agency; support an internship program where graduates from the University of Liberia and/or other partner institutions may be trained on applied conservation and ecological research; ensure Sapo NP bio-monitoring team members are fully equipped to continue to collect and analyze data on biological indicators for park management; and monitor and describe trends in chimpanzee distribution and density and relations between distribution and major identified threats on an annual basis.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Strengthening West African Chimpanzee Conservation Through a National Capacity Building Program in Conservation Research, Monitoring and Protected Area Management in the Sapo-Tai Region, Liberia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to contribute to the conservation of the West African chimpanzee in Liberia by building the capacity of natural resource managers to conduct applied research. Specific activities include: (1) increasing and supporting Liberian capacity to conduct research and biomonitoring activities through courses, provision of appropriate equipment, data analysis, internships and dissemination of results; (2) increasing Liberian capacity to manage protected areas through training courses and field activities in buffer zone demarcation; (3) understanding drivers of land use through engagement with local stakeholders and investigating buffer zone use; and (4) exploring human-animal conflict around Sapo National Park through interviews, site visits and community meetings to produce a collaborative monitoring plan.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Protecting Conservation Priority Area "Gbi" as a refuge for Liberia's largest chimpanzee population

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to protect conservation priority areas as a refuge for Liberia's largest wild chimpanzee population. Specific activities include: 1) confirming the Gbi proposed protected area as a priority hotspot for chimpanzee conservation in Liberia; and 2) developing community support towards conservation of a previously unmanaged area.

title.narrative: LIBERIA SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION PROJECT

description.narrative: The recipient will train community members to conduct daily patrols along 18 km of nesting beach in River Cess County to count and protect nests and nesting females, provide environmental education programs at local schools, and assist communities to develop alternative livelihood sources as a replacement from traditional consumption of turtles and eggs. The recipient will also organize and train community members in the communities of Bassa Point, Little Bassa and Edina to conduct daily patrols to count and protect nesting sea turtles and nests during the nesting season, develop educational conservation oriented materials and conduct community education and outreach programs.

title.narrative: Implementation of a participatory management plan to secure protection of western chimpanzee populations within and around Sapo National Park, Liberia

description.narrative: he purpose of this 18-month project is to conserve the western chimpanzee in Liberia by decreasing anthropogenic threats to chimpanzee populations within Sapo National Park (SNP) and its buffer zone. Specific activities include: 1) increasing legal enforcement and biomonitoring within the park; 2) supporting establishment of a community advisory board to engage on re-demarcation and management of the park; and 3) increasing protection for chimpanzee habitat in the park and buffer-zone.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Improved Protection of Krahn-Bassa Conservation Priority Area, refuge for one of Liberia's largest chimpanzee population

description.narrative: The purpose of this 2-year project is to continue to protect a conservation priority area as a refuge for Liberias largest wild chimpanzee population by establishing the Krahn-Bassa Protected Area (KBPA). Specific activities include: 1) engaging local communities in the creation and management of the proposed KBPA; 2) establishing a community-based ecoguard program in the proposed KBPA; 3) conducting community consultation meetings for the final approval of the KBPA creation, and establishing and marking its boundaries; 4) engaging community members in conservation through the use of community theater; 5) developing basic community-based ecotourism; 6) conducting community ecoguard missions to map other land uses within the proposed KBPA; 7) holding national-level consultation on KBPA creation, including awareness raising through radio; and 8) completing, and submitting to the Liberian forestry and legislative authorities for ratification, the KBPA proposal file.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Agency for International Development, Development Assistance

title.narrative: Liberia Sea Turtle Project: Support for Community-Based Marine Turtle Conservation Project in.Little Bassa and Borgor Point

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to develop a sea turtle conservation program in Liberia with on the ground community based conservation projects. Liberia's nesting sea turtle populations are depleted from overexploitation but has important foraging grounds along its entire coastline and nesting beach habitat intact and suitable for recovering sea tulle populations. The intent is to work with local communities to protect turtles on nesting beaches from poaching and work with fisherman from to safely release accidentally captured sea turtles in fishing gear. Activities include: 1) training community members to conduct daily patrols along 18 km of nesting beach in River Cess County to count and protect nests and nesting females, 2) train community members in the communities of Bassa Point, Little Bassa and Edina to conduct daily patrols to count and protect nesting sea turtles and nests during the nesting season, 3) training monitors to collect sea turtle bycatch data and strategic fisherman landing sites and to work teach fisherman safe handling and release techniques for accidental captured turtles, and 4) provide environmental education programs at local schools, and assist communities to develop alternative livelihood sources as a replacement from traditional consumption of turtles and eggs.

title.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION PROGRAM IN LIBERIA WITH ON THE GROUND COMMUNITY BASED CONSERVATION PROJECTS. LIBERIA'S NESTING SEA TURTLE POPULATIONS ARE DEPLETED

description.narrative: LIBERIA HAS IMPORTANT FORAGING GROUNDS ALONG ITS ENTIRE COASTLINE. THE NESTING BEACH HABITAT IS INTACT AND SUITABLE FOR RECOVERING MARINE TURTLE POPULATIONS. BUT THESE NESTING MARINE TURTLE POPULATIONS ARE DEPLETED FROM OVEREXPLOITATION.THE PROJECT TITLED STRENGTHENING THE COMMUNITY-BASED MARINE TURTLE CONSERVATION PROGRAM AND THE MARINE TURTLE BYCATCH MONITORING PROGRAM , WHICH IS CURRENTLY ON-GOING IN LITTLE BASSA, HAS BEEN WORKING TO HALTING THE DECLINE OF MARINE TURTLES WITHIN THE TARGETED AREA.THE PROJECT SEEKS TO PREVENT POACHING OF NESTS AND NESTING FEMALE TURTLES ALONG 22 KM OF BEACH AND TO REDUCE CONSUMPTION OF INCIDENTALLY CAPTURED LEATHERBACKS FISHING COMMUNITIES. THE MAIN PROJECT ACTIVITIES INVOLVED 1) TRAINING, 2) COMMUNITY BEACH PATROLLING 3) MONITORING OF LOCAL FISHERIES 4) CONSERVATION EDUCATION AND COMMUNITY OUTREACH THROUGH INFORMAL MEETINGS, AND 5) RADIO AWARENESS PROGRAM.

title.narrative: An integrated population viability analysis and Open Standards planning approach for species conservation planning of the West African Chimpanzee in the Republic of Liberia - Preproposal

description.narrative: The purpose of this 3-year project is to reduce the extinction risk of chimpanzees in Liberia by 2030 by modifying risky human behaviors. Activities include: 1) conduct a comprehensive threats analysis to determine threats to chimpanzee long-term survival; 2) identifying which of those threats are driven by human behaviors, and to what degree; 3) conduct a population viability analysis mathematical modeling exercise to identify those human-driven behaviors having the greatest negative impact on chimpanzee extinction risk; and 4) designing and implementing broad behavior change strategy to address the highest priority behaviors.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

title.narrative: An integrated population viability analysis and Open Standards planning approach for species conservation planning of the West African Chimpanzee in the Republic of Liberia - Preproposal

description.narrative: The purpose of this two-year project is to use acoustic recording devices to provide information about imperiled forest elephants that are very costly to monitor by direct observation or traditional transects. These funds will support (1) a monitoring program at the Dzanga Bai, a forest clearing in Central African Republic and an important source of wildlife management data as the site of the worlds longest running individual-based study of African forest elephants; and (2) a regional program to link and improve the science of biologists and field technicians using acoustic monitoring for wildlife management in Africa.

title.narrative: COMMUNITY ECOGUARDS PROVIDE IMPROVED PROTECTION FOR WESTERN CHIMPANZEES AT KRAHN-BASSA PROPOSED PROTECTED AREA, SOUTHEASTERN LIBERIA

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT THE SECOND LARGEST POPULATION OF ENDANGERED WESTERN CHIMPANZEES IN LIBERIA THROUGH GAZETTEMENT OF THE KRAHN BASSA PROPOSED PROTECTED AREA (KBPPA) AS LIBERIA S LARGEST NATIONAL PARK BY (1) INCREASING THE NUMBER OF COMMUNITY ECOMONITORING TEAMS, IMPLEMENTING SMART DATA COLLECTION, AND SHARING OF INFORMATION WITH THE PARK AUTHORITIES (2) INCREASING LOCAL COMMUNITIES AWARENESS OF HUMAN CHIMP CONFLICT AND HOW TO AVOID IT AND (3) IMPROVING COMMUNITY ECOMONITORING COLLABORATION WITH LIBERIA S WILDLIFE CRIME TASK FORCE THROUGH INCREASED TRAINING, COMMUNICATION, AND JOINT MONITORING ACTIVITIES.

title.narrative: COMMUNITY ECOGUARDS PROVIDE IMPROVED PROTECTION FOR WESTERN CHIMPANZEES AT KRAHN-BASSA PROPOSED PROTECTED AREA, SOUTHEASTERN LIBERIA

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT THE SECOND LARGEST POPULATION OF ENDANGERED WESTERN CHIMPANZEES IN LIBERIA THROUGH GAZETTEMENT OF THE KRAHN-BASSA PROPOSED PROTECTED AREA KBPPA AS LIBERIA S LARGEST NATIONAL PARK BY 1 INCREASING THE NUMBER OF COMMUNITY ECOMONITORING TEAMS, IMPLEMENTING SMART DATA COLLECTION, AND SHARING OF INFORMATION WITH THE PARK AUTHORITIES 2 INCREASING LOCAL COMMUNITIES AWARENESS OF HUMAN-CHIMP CONFLICT AND HOW TO AVOID IT AND 3 IMPROVING COMMUNITY ECOMONITORING COLLABORATION WITH LIBERIA S WILDLIFE CRIME TASK FORCE THROUGH INCREASED TRAINING, COMMUNICATION, AND JOINT MONITORING ACTIVITIES.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: COMMUNITY ECOGUARDS PROVIDE IMPROVED PROTECTION FOR WESTERN CHIMPANZEES AT KRAHN-BASSA PROPOSED PROTECTED AREA, SOUTHEASTERN LIBERIA

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to protect the second largest population of endangered western chimpanzees.in Liberia through gazettement of the Krahn-Bassa Proposed Protected Area (KBPPA) as Liberias.largest national park by: (1) increasing the number of community ecomonitoring teams, implementing.SMART data collection, and sharing of information with the park authorities; (2) increasing local.communities awareness of human-chimp conflict and how to avoid it; and (3) improving community.ecomonitoring collaboration with Liberias Wildlife Crime Task Force through increased training,.communication, and joint monitoring activities.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date
